personalInfo.clubAffl: Club de Golf México (Mexico City, Mexico)

tourBios.carHigh:
2015: Played in five Web.com Tour events, making three cuts with five top 25s. Finished 91st on the money list…Missed the cut at the Mexico Championship in his first start of the year in April…Monday-qualified for the Digital Ally Open in August. Entered the final round T24 and moved up 21 spots with an 8-under 63 to claim a T3 in his second Tour start…By virtue of his finish in Kansas City, earned a spot in the next week's Price Cutter Charity Championship. Went into the final round solo fourth. Shot even-par 72 to fall into a T16…Added a T13 in his last Web.com Tour start of the year, at the WinCo Portland Open… Had a very consistent season on PGA TOUR Latinoamérica, where he finished 7th on the Order of Merit… Had six top-10s and nine top-25s in 16 starts… His best finish was T2 at the Volvo Colombian Classic, where he missed a four-footer for par on the 72nd hole that would have forced a playoff… Posted a T3 at the Lexus Peru Open in November and a T4 at the Lexus Panama Classic in May… Had a Tour record of 19 consecutive cuts made snapped when withdrawing due to back pain at the Mundo Maya Open in October.

2014: Made the cut in 7 of his 12 starts on the Web.com Tour. Finished the regular season ranked 122nd on the money list. His only top-10 was T5 at the Louisiana Open in March… Made his return to PGA TOUR Latinoamérica in September, collecting four top-20s in as many starts. His top finishes were T6 at the Ecuador Open and T7 at the Lexus Peru Open. With those results, he managed to finish the season ranked 58th on the Order of Merit to secure exempt status for 2015. 

2013: Finished the PGA TOUR Latinoamérica season ranked 16th on the Order of Merit. Had four top-10s and seven top-25s while making the cut in 10 of 13 starts. His best finish was T4 at the Roberto De Vicenzo Invitational Copa NEC in Uruguay, where he carded a 69 on the final round to finish only one stroke outside a three-man playoff for the title… Finished T57 at the Puerto Rico Open on his first career start on the PGA TOUR… Was one for two in cuts made on the Web.com Tour. Did not advance to the weekend at the Mexico Championship but did so at the Price Cutter Charity Championship, where he was a Monday qualifier… Closed the year with a T26 finish at the Web.com Tour Q-School final to earn status for the 2014 season. Opened that event at PGA West in California with scores of 71-75-74 and was T135 after 54 holes, but made a strong comeback with rounds of 63-66-68.

2012: In only his second start as a pro on PGA TOUR Latinoamérica he went on to win the Puerto Rico Classic in early November. Shot 65-72-66-71 for a winning score of 14-under 274. Defeated Argentina's Jorge Fernández-Valdés by two strokes. As winner of that event, the Puerto Rico Golf Association awarded him an invitation to play the PGA TOUR's Puerto Rico Open presented by seepuertorico.com in March of 2013… Made his debut as a professional by finishing T17 at the PGA TOUR Latinoamérica's Lexus Peru Open during the first week of November… Finished the season ranked No. 12 on the PGA TOUR Latinoamérica Order of Merit… Joined the Latinoamérica Tour by finishing T18 at the Q-School played at the Doral's White Course in August.
tourBios.otherCarHigh: Finished in a T4 at the PGA TOUR Latinoamérica's season-opening Mundo Maya Open, an event in which he carded a course record-tying 64 in the third round…Won the Mexican Amateur Championship in 2011 and 2012… Finished third at the 2012 U.S. Amateur stroke-play competition and then lost in the first round of stroke play...Earned low individual honors at the 2012 World Amateur Team Championship in Turkey. Posted rounds of 66-67-66 for a 54-hole total of 15-under and a one-shot win over the U.S.'s Chris Williams. Became the first Mexican to win the WATC's individual title since Víctor Regalado in 1970.
tourBios.personal: Has two younger brothers… The golf instructors he has worked with are Alejandro Muñoz and Gary Gilchrist… Hobbies include playing poker… His favorite golf course is Sunnehanna Country Club in Westmont, Pennsylvania… Drives a Jeep Cherokee… His favorite teams are the Auburn Tigers (college sports) and Spain's Real Madrid… Favorite book is “Outliers: The Story of Success”… Favorite TV show is “Prison Break” and his favorite movies “Savages” and “Scarface”… Japanese food is his favorite… Tiger Woods is his favorite athlete… New York and Miami are his favorite cities, while his favorite vacation spot is Acapulco, Mexico… Bucket list includes winning The Masters… His favorite quote is: “Never give up.”… Instagram: @sebastianvazquezc

tourBios.exmtStatus: Conditional - Finished T123 at 2015 Web.com Tour Qualifying Tournament

2011: Missed the cut in the Web.com Tour's Mexico Open, where he was playing as an amateur.
tourBios.otherCarHigh: Won the Mexican Amateur Championship in 2011 and 2012…Finished third at the 2012 U.S. Amateur's stroke-play competition and then lost in the first round of match play...Earned low individual honors at the 2012 World Amateur Team Championship in Turkey. Posted rounds of 66-67-66 for a 54-hole total of 15-under and a one-shot win over the U.S.'s Chris Williams. Became the first Mexican to win the WATC's individual title since Víctor Regalado in 1970.
tourBios.personal: Attended Anahuac University in Mexico City and is expected to graduate with a business degree in 2014...Says if he weren't playing golf as a professional he'd be a businessman...Favorite course is Mayakoba and would like to play Augusta National...Favorite teams are Real Madrid and LSU...Favorite TV show is "Prison Break," and movie is "Scarface."...Like Japanese food and carries Power Bars in his bag as a snack...Favorite athlete in another sport is Michael Jordan...Likes to visit Acapulco...Would include Tiger Woods, Adam Scott and Jason Day in a dream foursome... Instagram: @sebastianvazquezc

dyn.dynResults: His best finish on the PGA TOUR Latinoameri in 2016 is T39th at the 69 Avianca Colombia Open presentado por BBVA.
dyn.dynStats: He ranks T35th in Scoring Average (Actual) on the Latinoamérica.
